awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bridging the Gap Between Particle-Scale Thermal - - Transport and Device-scale Predictions
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how heat is transported in gas-particle mixtures is critical to improving the performance, efficiency and reliability of clean energy technologies and predicting environmental flows. The conversion of coal and biomass into useful fuel, thermal storage by particulate material, and particle-based solar receivers, all represent promising technologies that rely heavily on heat transfer in multiphase systems. Current tools used in industry and academia rely on simplistic models for average reaction rates as well as heat transfer coefficients that are known to vary by several orders of magnitude. This project introduces a new modeling approach that will enable researchers to address the huge range of challenges associated with heat transfer through gas-particle mixtures. For a broader educational impact, a toy version of a fluidized bed will be built with beads sprayed with thermochromic liquid crystals that change color with temperature. This will be presented at local schools to illustrate fundamental concepts of fluid-particle interactions.

In this project, researchers from Michigan, Iowa State, and Minnesota collaborate to develop a new paradigm in multiphase heat transfer modeling. The aim is to bridge the gap between particle-scale thermal processes and device-scale predictions. A consistent modeling framework is formulated that scales from a well-accepted physics-based model to a larger scale of interest. Current approaches typically ensemble-average data obtained from the microscale physics directly, without taking into account local variations on scales resolvable by the simulation framework. The proposed effort will connect the spatially-averaged, large-scale representation to two-phase statistics obtained from particle-resolved numerical simulations. A previously overlooked ergodic consistency requirement will be enforced so that the numerical solution converges to the ensemble-averaged two-fluid equations in the limit of large filter width. Model validation will be based on simultaneous multi-camera imaging at different scales, and a novel application of Voronoi tessellation to quantify clustering in dense suspensions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dense fluid-particle systems are common in both natural and industrial processes, ranging from cloud formation to fluidized bed reactors and swimming microorganisms. The thermal transport in these systems is important, as understanding it is crucial for improving the performance, efficiency, and reliability of clean and affordable energy conversion processes, as well as predicting environmental flows. In this study, we combined experimental methods and numerical simulations to investigate dense fluid-particle systems.

To study dense gas-solid flow experimentally, we constructed a three-dimensional riser reactor at the University of Minnesota. In this device, spherical particles are fed from the top while air flows upward to extend particle persistence time in the observation regions. By controlling both the number of particles and air velocity, we could examine a wide range of experimental parameters, including solid volume fraction and Reynolds number. This research led to the first laboratory observation of cluster-induced turbulence, a phenomenon where particles concentrate in certain regions, forming what we call particle clusters. Our study identified a threshold solid volume fraction of 0.5% for cluster formation, which remained consistent across the Reynolds numbers examined. Space-time autocorrelations revealed dense and persistent structures with typical vertical lengths comparable to the channel width. These structures fell faster than average particles and left long wakes. Through tracking and analysis, we characterized these clusters by their size, shape, location, and descent velocity. The clusters showed distinct characteristics: they were highly elongated vertically, often exceeding the channel width, predominantly appeared near the wall, and descended faster than surrounding dilute particles. We also found that larger clusters were denser, longer-lived, and had higher descent velocities, though their speed showed minimal variation with distance from the wall.

Our numerical investigation employed two different approaches: the Eulerian-Lagrangian method and particle-resolved simulation. For the Eulerian-Lagrangian method, our formulation captured both momentum and heat transfer through carefully constructed governing equations. Besides solid particles, we also developed the ability to study particle droplets by considering humidity and water exchange between droplets and surrounding flows. In our simulations, we studied particles of different sizes in turbulent flow, where we observed that smaller particles exhibited tracer-like characteristics while larger particles showed more independent trajectories.

For particle-resolved simulations, we implemented the direct-forcing immersed boundary method and an adaptive time linearized spring-dashpot model for particle-particle interactions. While the high computational costs prevented direct simulation of the experimental setup, we conducted several related simulations. These included studies of freely falling monodisperse particle arrays, which demonstrated cluster-induced turbulence and showed trailing particles rapidly approaching leading particles. We also investigated particle shape effects in channel flow over a wall of movable particles and in immersed column collapse problems. These studies revealed that while all cases showed wave-like wall structure formation, different particle shapes exhibited distinct behaviors. Spherical particles showed higher mean velocities and preferred rolling motion, while oblate particles tended toward sliding motions in dense systems. Our analysis of shear stress highlighted the importance of incorporating particle shape in future fluid-particle system modeling. In the column collapse studies, spherical particles achieved maximum runout distance and showed the most movement and angular velocity, while oblate particles exhibited minimal movement.

This research significantly advances our understanding of fluid-particle systems and their behavior under various conditions. The findings have important implications for improving industrial processes, environmental modeling, and the development of more efficient clean energy technologies. Future work can build upon these results to develop more accurate models and better predict the behavior of complex fluid-particle systems in both natural and engineered environments.
